text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new Kurt Vile LP neo on a
pretty days Kurt Vile is a Philadelphia
guitar player and singer songwriter who
first started gaining momentum in the
late 2000s on a wave of popularity for
lo-fi and home recorded music though the
album constant hit maker in 2008 was not
Vile's first LP it was an album where
you could hear him moaning in on the
sound that he would refine on later
releases now this LP in particular had a
lot of just bare simple indie folk tunes
that sometimes were very straightforward
and minimal and other times very
psychedelic layered and hazy that more
psychedelic side of vials musical
persona was growing as he put out more
releases until about 2010 when he really
sort of had his first big breakthrough
with the album smoke ring for my halo an
album that I did not review the year it
came out mostly because of just some
very strong negative reactions to a few
characteristics for one though I did
like that the production was very sort
of lush and and hazy and very
psychedelic it made a lot of the songs
feel so uniform throughout and on top of
that I didn't really feel all that much
love for vile as a lyricist though I
haven't always been impressed with vile
stuff once I dig a little bit deeper
into it I've always thought that there
is a certain charm to his slow tone down
drawl doubt vocals style he always tries
to surround himself with the most
vibrant sounds that he can and his voice
sort of explains things as he's singing
in an inflection that's reminiscent of
someone like Lou Reed I like these
things about Kurt's style but there are
times when I listen to his music and I
feel like he keeps his lyrics his song
structures and his melodies ultra ultra
simple just for the sake of maintaining
this style and maintaining this vibe
this very sort of psychedelic homogenous
vibe that is really only interesting on
a surface level and even though that
sort of lucid and very subdued vibe
contain
this new LP as well anyway Kurt kind of
turns a new leaf and becomes
surprisingly ambitious on a lot of these
tracks on this 70 minute album I change
some of the psychedelic haze gets put on
the back burner with some of these
tracks in favor of some stopping
baselines a little bit of cowbell some
very sharp guitar leads and phrasing
it's definitely reminiscent of artists
like Bruce Springsteen or even Tom Petty
and the Heartbreakers this is especially
true of a track like Cavey crimes where
the guitar phrasing on this song feels
almost like arena rock guitars but of
course they're sort of very lightly
distorted and modestly played but the
bass line man it really struts out there
on this track locked in step with the
drums like it is the of the walk
the song shame chamber too is one of the
catchiest and most concise songs Kurt
Vile has written yet really stepping
beyond the psychedelic sounds and
writing a song that feels really really
confident strong hook strong riffing and
a very clear emotional message coming
through on the lyrics and on the song
snowflakes are dancing it feels like
some of Kurt's old ideas are being
revitalized to be something way more
straightforward and just sharp some very
Neil Young inspired chords on this song
the song is kind of psychedelic and the
drums behind this track really punched
through the A's and drive this song
confidently which is kind of an idea a
style that Kurt has explored on previous
tracks as well as in the band the war on
drugs
Kurt's voice is front Center on this
song too he is a very convincing
vocalist in my opinion not necessarily
the best singer in the world
but he's very sincere in a lot of his
songs my only issue with this track
though is I'm not really in love with
some of the lyrics snowflakes are
dancing discman is pumping headphones
are loud chilling on a pillowy cloud
while you're at it
add some Doritos and a bike it and some
slippers or a cup of chamomile tea
you know honestly when it comes to
lyrics I'm not incredibly picky I don't
need a lot of flowery language if you're
a longtime viewer of my reviews you may
know at this point that I don't even
really dwell over leer
that often but there are some times
where I feel like the lyrics are unag
Nora belong the song because they come
off as just being so vapid like on the
song too hard where Kurt seems to be
making all these promises just out of
nowhere he promises to smoke less he
promises to do his best for his God in
his country he promises not to party too
hard then later into the song he says
that a man has to hold tight to the
heart of the matter at hand and you know
I agree
throughout this track Kurt makes a lot
of promises to himself or someone else
I'm not sure and just a lot of agreeable
statements about maybe life or just his
philosophy but it doesn't really seem
like it's pointing to anything
thankfully the production and the
instrumentation is gorgeous
it's just kind of disappointing to see
how beautiful the sounds and just the
instrumentation is on this album its
blissful it's heavenly but then some of
the lyrics just are so plain this is the
case as well the song was all talked
recur kind of falls back into his old
ways by writing a song that sonically
feels pretty homogeneous from beginning
to end the production is slightly more
lush than the stuff from smoke ring and
I do like that the song is a little
hypnotic but Kurt spits out this one
line where he's like makin music is easy
watch me if that was the point Kurt was
trying to prove it this song I agree I
feel the same way about the song err but
to with how homogeneous it feels from
beginning to end not quite so bad there
are some very fast since that pop in and
out of this track that I like again
these are not really terrible songs in
my opinion I just feel like they could
be more interesting especially with what
Kurt brings vocally thankfully that's
really it for the songs on here that I
feel sort of indifferent toward other
tracks on here the vast majority of the
tracks on here I actually think are
great like the opening track on this
thing the nine-minute not a pretty day a
really awesomely grooving and sublime
full rocker sharp guitar leads all over
this thing cut through the psychedelic
haze I love the stop that they do in the
middle of this track the sort of segue
that they play into immediately after
the feels almost linear
skynyrd inspired the song girl called
Alex appeals to me as well in a lot of
the same ways the song never run away is
one of the sharpest singles Kurt Vile
has written yet one of the shorter songs
on this LP really catchy refrain verses
with a lot of momentum being driven by
some rhythm guitar just very punchy
drums and another track I love on this
LP the 10-minute clothes are gold-tone
which is a spot on this album where Kurt
again goes back into that sort of
personal musing mode of his where he's
giving a lot of personal thoughts
feelings but on this song they come off
in a way that feels sort of reasoned or
sensible in a way that the listener can
actually relate or just understand
brokers coming from he says right at the
beginning of the song that when he gets
into his zone he gets into this mental
state where if you saw him it would seem
as if he is high so he says in the song
he's never touched this stuff then he
goes on to say this personal pain that
he feels he tries to basically exorcise
it get rid of it dump it through
creating gold tones just pretty sounding
music sounds that he feels are beautiful
or sweet which to me says a lot about
the makeup of this album philosophically
and musically it's basically a
behind-the-scenes look at Kurt's mental
state when he goes into the songwriting
process but aside from the mental state
of this track the instrumental is
beautiful as well again a sublime
instrumental closing out this album I'm
absolutely in love with the
instrumentation on this thing it is so
lovely is there vibraphone on this track
it is so pretty with that the acoustic
guitar the bass the drums the vocals
they all blend together into yet another
haze and yes there is a lot of haze on
this album but there's a lot of detail
and lushness to the haziness i mean it's
all just so dense and detailed and
that's what I really love about this LP
though I don't think this is a perfect
album it is Kurt Vile best yet and there
is reason to believe that his next album
could be even better because up until
this point with every new release Kurt
Vile has improved upon what he did
before he shows more
more ambition every year and even though
I haven't been a huge fan of Curt vials
for a majority of his career that does
make me excited for the future I'm
feeling a light eight on the selfie if
you've given to listen what did you
think of it did you love it did you hate
it why what do you think I should review
next and that's it
Anthony Fantan oh all down a pretty days
forever
